comments.commentBody:
Well stated, Patrick. I believe that inheritances should be capped, maybe at a million, then taxed at 100%. We can use the additional revenue to bolster the safety net and to lower income taxes. That may not be appealing to the country club set, or the capital gains crowd, but it works just fine for this center-right commenter who'll be voting for the democrat for president this fall (for the first time in 30 years).

Our nation prides itself on an entrepreneurial, can-do spirit. There should be no need for a defacto aristocracy. Let's help those who need help, and the rest of us can earn our way. Random membership in the lucky sperm club is meaningless. Wise members tend to remember that.

For the cell phone owners:
1) you can put a code or pin number before anyone can reach you.
2) you can assign different ring tones to your friends phone calls which will tell you who is calling.

For the landlines: copy the phone company message and put it on your answering device that says: "We are sorry the number you've reached has been discontinued and there is no new number" But to obviate alarming your mom tell her she should keep on holding until she starts leaving a message.

My father taught his five children by example that giving money to those in need is a "given". He learned that from his parents and I assume they learned that from theirs.. I just assumed that everyone knew that ! I suppose I am awfully naive. I know many wealthy individuals, most of whom, are very philanthropic and are involved in giving not only of their money but of their time to multiple organizations. My parents gave money even when they didn't have much to give.
Please don't lose heart. There are good people out there who think of others less fortunate than themselves.
I had the good fortune to be raised by such parents.

I have been a professional fundraiser for 25 years for some of the best schools in the country. I've loved helping really wealthy people and just some generous folks to give back to organizations I have served or to other charities they prefer. This article is very well-written because it accents that not everyone with money is instantly comfortable with being "wealthy" (other useful adjectives are affluent, fortunate, lucky, etc.) I have heard wealthy people use words such as cursed, constrained, overwhelmed, and others that are not understood as positive. It was nice that the writer mentioned a family in which the parents instructed their sons that they were expected to be charitable (e.g. "give back"). As a professional asker, I have met too many wealthy people whose values did not include being philanthropic and, as I tell students to whom I teach fundraising now, nothing any non-family member can say will convince them to be philanthropic if the family tree in which the money was earned and/or passed from generation to generation did not get joy from helping others. I still believe deeply that the wealthy (those in any income tax bracket higher than 28% and everyone who might ever pay the 15% capital gain tax rate, like Mr. Romney's family who pay only 15% because it's legal) can do so much more than they do, but that's my idealism at work. With $42 Trillion being passed down, it should be "easy" for those who get that money to help others greatly. Let's hope! Thank You!

lol, Jimbo.

Yes, I saw it, but only because you drew attention to it...

Glad that you did; it was a real 'Almost-made-this-reader-die' jest!

What is the average/median wage of those brought in under the H-1B program?  Overall?  By speciality (e.g. computer programmers, life science, etc.)?  Am curious what the profile is because it matters to another argument--if it is higher than the wage of a secondary math/science teacher (of which there is a shortage) than they are decreasing overall wage and making it more likely secondary schools can find at least some STEM teachers.

The Washington Post just published an article about the massive unemployment problem of American Ph.D.s in STEM career - "Even the Science PhDs are in troubles"

"http://www.washingtonmonthly.com/college_guide/blog/even_the_science_phd..."

What I want to know is that why the Brooking Institutes refuse to look at the fact regarding the H-1B program which is used mostly by Indian outsourcing companies? Furthermore, the increase in supply of STEMs lower American citizens' wages and opportunity. Why is there no limit on the H-1Bs sponsored by universities despite the surplus of American STEM Ph.D.?

Your studies also do not address the issues of discrimination against older American STEM workers and minorities. For example, American engineers over 40 year of age has a very high rate of unemployment in Silicon Valley. And since the H-1B came into existence, the number of African and Latino Americans who work in high-tech has plummeted. The San Jose Mercury News has published an article about the disappearance of high-tech workers from minorities group. Why your study doesn't address this issue?

The immigration and naturalization service is understaffed and dealing with confusing regulations apparently.  I came to this conclusion from reading a help column for immigration issues in the San Jose Mercury News for a number of years.  How can reforms be made when the current problems seem so daunting?

I used to hire H1 employees and they certainly did not make slave wages.  However, what india did to create this pool of workers was to go to the country and massively educate poor underprivileged workers .  Why don't we use stimulus money and do the same thing.

Basically, what we are seeing on the ground, is an extreme jobs shortage for qualified software engineers.  Recently we had an open position and received over 400 qualified applicants for this one job.   I spoke with some highly skilled, highly educated workers and they have not been able to find any work for 6 months due to the extreme jobs shortage.  So if workers wish to stay in their own countries, that would probably be a good career move as there is an extreme jobs shortage in the US.

Pete - What I am hearing from engineers is that there is an extreme jobs shortage.  You should be able to fill that position immediately.  You may not be taking a good approach to solve your problem.  I would suggest upgrading your skill set.

Pete, there are thousands of software engineers with graduate degrees around here who are unemployed or grossly underemployed, and if their skillset is slightly different from the exact list your teams are "asking for", in 11 weeks they are perfectly capable of learning the missing bits. Most of them will be quite happy with 130K pay. If your team is headed by the Indian, consists mostly of H1B Indians, and their requirements for the new hire can't be met unless he is an Indian, as a "HR dude" you should ask your management to review this.

Pete I agree that most H1B's are not working for "slave wages".

However, what they are working for, is starting salaries. Which is less than the salaries of the people they are replacing. And quite directly - replacing.

My firm hires H1B's while they lay off people with similar credentials. In the case of my group, the very same month - H1B STEM field PhD in, experienced STEM field PhD out. Not as a result of any performance problem. Rather, it was because my then-manager was instructed to identify someone in his group to make the numbers for a general layoff, the very same month the H1B he hired the month before was to report.

Now, the H1B is an excellent worker and fine person (and had no knowledge of this), but so was the one let go.

1) None of the persons you quoted are H-1B. I am sure most of them would qualify for the O-Visa program which is for people with extraordinary skills. Most American support people with extraordinary skills because their contributions are much greater and they do not compete with American citizens for jobs. The vast majority of H-1Bs (99.9%) do not fit into this category.

2. No, I don't think so. Most American are against the H-1B program from the beginning. It came into existence because our politicians have been bought by corporate interests.

3. Feel free to move to other countries. Good luck trying to find a job as a foreign guest worker in Europe or even Canada. Most European countries are already having big problem providing jobs for their citizens. In addition, because European citizens have the rights to work in any European country, these countries have to provide job opportunity to other European citizens as well. I don't see any reason why the U.K. or Germany want to take in a non-European foreign guest worker when an unemployed Greek is arriving in their countries. As a matter of fact, the U.K. and Germany want to severely limit the number of non-European immigrants coming into their countries. As for Canada, I have heard of numerous "high skilled" workers from India who drive taxis in Canada and most of them end up going to the U.S. for work anyway.

H1-B isn't a trampoline for a Green Card. It's a temporary visa for someone working temporarily in the U.S. An MBA isn't an extraordinary skill set, be it from a "top 5" school, which one gets into by acing the GMAT test. An M.D. isn't an extraordinary skill set, either. It's likely that working in finance doesn't involve the kinds of skills that qualify one for employment-based immigration through a Green Card.
Why disparage IT, and why say you're better than the average American? Is it surprising that the US immigration system "leans heavily" towards American businesses rather than, say, Indian H1-B workers and M.D.'s?
A points-based system is government-mandated, and this isn't how this country's free employment market operates.

To obtain access to the unmatched opportunities this country offers, I suggest you revise your estimates, accept you need more skills than you have to apply for a Green Card in today's economy, go back to school - perhaps for a finance or science PhD, competing with a far more qualified cohort than ten years ago - and work your way in then up. That's the American way.

Another option, far more common, is to wait it out and count on your kid born in the U.S. to get you a Green Card once they're 18. That's the sleazy way in, and not what this country is about.

Further, all of the persons mentioned above, except for Albert Einstein, went to elementary, middle and high school, college and science graduate school in the US. They are products of this country's education and culture together with each of their unique individual family backgrounds. Andy Grove went to college and grad school in the U.S. as well, though his parents stayed behind in Hungary.

Hi,

I would like to start by providing a brief background about myself

-H1B with an MBA from top 5 school in the US
-Worked in finance for top tier banks and strategy consulting - NOT in IT
-My wife is a doctor and treats patients in under served areas
-H1-B visa for past ten years and possibly another 10 before we get a Green Card if at all
- Paid more in taxes, SS and Medicare than average American citizens of our age - BTW, we don't even get to use SS and Medicare

My question for the broader panel are as follows:

1) Does US, the land of immigrants, recognize the contributions made by immigrants to the American economy and way of life - Albert Einstein, Google (Sergey Brin), Apple (Andy Grove), Yahoo (Jerry Yang), Youtube (Jawed Karim), eBay (Pierre Omidyar)?

2) Does absence of credible solutions for the current economic mess and high unemployment rate make highly educated "legal" immigrants easy scapegoats for everything gone wrong in the USA

3) Would the current anti-immigrant sentiment discourage next generation of entrepreneurs and engineers / doctors from coming to the US and instead moving to other countries? - BTW already happening

4) Does the current US immigration system, which leans heavily in favor of the employers rather than the H1-B workers, actually enable employers to exploit / arm twist their employees? Would it help to just move to a more transparent points based system like other developed countries? Why is this being delayed?

I would ask the broader panel to publish data on the nationalities of students / professionals graduating (phd's / engineers / MBAs) from top 10 universities (forget top 20 or 30) in the US

Please also provide patent application / approvals data by nationality if available. If I remember correctly, ~40% patent applications are filed by immigrants who then move on to the H1-B visa. BTW those patents are then used by American companies to build stronger businesses and create jobs

Further, please provide data, if available, on number of firms started by immigrants in past 10 years and the number of jobs created by them

Thanks
Michael

That is a great point Bill. That is why the immigration system needs to be fixed so that no one has to wait 6, 10, 20 years to get a green card. I do not have a GC but own 2 houses and so do my friends. Lets join hands to revive America!

Thanks
Michael

There are not that many highly skilled "young" people willing to move to the RUST BELT so H1-B's are needed to replenish the work force as the baby boomers are retiring.

We do need more Americans to move from states like NY and CA to move to the rust belt of Ohio and Iowa to bring down the unemployment rate.

Further the high pension and healthcare costs of retiring baby boomers are probably a big factor on cost reduction initiatives for outsourcing leading to a downturn.

I have friends that are hiring so I can get you in touch.

I trust you did not actually remit the $500/hour where you had to train them

Big firms know their young lawyers know nothing.

For most of the people who go to law school, a $60K per year starting salary more than justifies law school.

The average humanities or social science major graduating from college makes $30K per year to start.

The average starting salary for law grads is actually between $70K and $80K, as the chart in the article shows, and those numbers are pushed way down by people doing a clerkship for a year or two who will see a huge boost in their incomes once they go into the private sector.

The only people who can make anywhere near what a lawyer can make right out of college are Engineers and C.S. majors, and if they go to law school, they'll typically make $150K to $200K to start at a Patent law firm.

The only people who wouldn't make more money going to law school are:

1. The tiny number of people who can get jobs in sales and trading at the prop desk of a bank or a hedge fund

2. People who can get into medical school or dental school.

If you aren't a math or science wiz, law school is your best shot at making into the upper middle class.

Isn't that rather like offering to return the meal after you've already chewed it?

The school already put a lot of resources into training this law student. I don't know how they can accept returns--it's a service, not a product, and one generally can't return services like medical procedures, vacations, meals, or degrees.

But perhaps this sloppy thinking explains why this Boston College law graduate can't find a job.

Yes. They are suing, and the law schools keep winning.

The cases against New York Law School and Thomas Cooley law school were both thrown out at an early stage of the litigation.

Anyone with a law degree can bring a frivolous law suit.

If they actually win a law suit, then we can start talking.

Take a look at the government data. These figures are actually way too low.

The median lawyer, at mid-career, is making $115K, and that excludes law firm partners. Mean is $130K per year. Unemployment rate? 2-3%

You can see the data here:
http://www.askapeer.com/pages/labor-market-data

And compare law to other fields here:
http://www.askapeer.com/pages/compare-jobs

The median lawyer makes $130K per year. The median actor makes 32K per year.

The unemployment rate for lawyers is less than 3%. The unemployment rate for actors is more than 35%.

Heaven help you if you think being a lawyer is anything like being an actor.

Source:
http://www.askapeer.com/pages/labor-market-data

1. The number of persons employed in the economy over the past year have increased (see the main blog entry!); however, not enough to keep pace with the increase in the working-age population and certainly not enough to reduce the rate of unemployment. To do the latter, jobs need to be created faster than the rate of increase in the number of persons in the workforce. The fact that employment is increasing at an insufficient rate is not inconsistent with the fact that withholding taxes have increased 3.6 percent year-over-year;

2. You are comparing *nominal* payroll withholding year-over-year and not withholding in real money terms. While the rate of inflation was not very high over the past 12 months, it was about 2 percent. Wages normally increase with inflation and economists have been surprised that wages have not decreased so far---Google "sticky wages". Wages have been very sticky in this recession;

3. The average number of hours worked have increased somewhat over the past 12 months and the number of overtime numbers slightly more, even though the number of jobs created has been modest. Increased hours worked means higher payroll taxes. See June to June BLS statistics;

4. Re: #2, the US tax codes is partially indexed for inflation, but not completely so. There is a natural bias towards higher taxes along with inflation.

Add it all up and the payroll data is more or less consistent with the unemployment data.
